#Text=CHAPTER
#Text=XXX — THE LETTER FROM THE SHIP
#Text=Daylight showed us how solitary the inn stood .
#Text=It was plainly hard upon the sea , yet out of all view of it , and beset on every side with scabbit hills of sand .
#Text=There was , indeed , only one thing in the nature of a prospect , where there stood out over a brae the two sails of a windmill , like an ass ’s ears , but with the ass quite hidden .
#Text=It was strange ( after the wind rose , for at first it was dead calm ) to see the turning and following of each other of these great sails behind the hillock .
#Text=Scarce any road came by there ; but a number of footways travelled among the bents in all directions up to Mr. Bazin ’s door .
#Text=The truth is , he was a man of many trades , not any one of them honest , and the position of his inn was the best of his livelihood .

#Text=Smugglers frequented it ; political agents and forfeited persons bound across the water came there to await their passages ; and I daresay there was worse behind , for a whole family might have been butchered in that house and nobody the wiser .
#Text=I slept little and ill .
#Text=Long ere it was day , I had slipped from beside my bedfellow , and was warming myself at the fire or walking to and fro before the door .
#Text=Dawn broke mighty sullen ; but a little after , sprang up a wind out of the west , which burst the clouds , let through the sun , and set the mill to the turning .
#Text=There was something of spring in the sunshine , or else it was in my heart ; and the appearing of the great sails one after another from behind the hill , diverted me extremely .
#Text=At times I could hear a creak of the machinery ; and by half-past eight of the day , and I thought this dreary , desert place was like a paradise .
#Text=For all which , as the day drew on and nobody came near , I began to be aware of an uneasiness that I could scarce explain .

#Text=It seemed there was trouble afoot ; the sails of the windmill , as they came up and went down over the hill , were like persons spying ; and outside of all fancy , it was surely a strange neighbourhood and house for a young lady to be brought to dwell in .

#Text=At breakfast , which we took late , it was manifest that James More was in some danger or perplexity ; manifest that Alan was alive to the same , and watched him close ; and this appearance of duplicity upon the one side , and vigilance upon the other , held me on live coals .
#Text=The meal was no sooner over than James seemed to come began to make apologies .
#Text=He had an appointment of a private nature in the town ( it was with the French nobleman , he told me ) , and we would please excuse him till about noon .
#Text=Meanwhile he carried his daughter aside to the far end of the room , where he seemed to speak rather earnestly and she to listen with much inclination .
#Text=“ I am caring less and less about this man James , ” said Alan .
#Text=“ There ’s something no right with the man James , and I shouldnae wonder but what Alan Breck would give an eye to him this day .
#Text=I would like fine to see yon French nobleman , Davie ; and I daresay you could find an employ to yoursel , and that would be to speir at the lassie for some news o ’ your affair .

#Text=Just tell it to her plainly — tell her ye ’re a muckle ass at the off-set ; and then , if I were you , and ye could do it naitural , I would just mint to her I was in some kind of a danger ; a ’ weemenfolk likes that . ”
#Text=“ I cannae lee , Alan , I cannae do it naitural , ” says I , mocking him .
#Text=“ The more fool you ! ” says he .
#Text=“ Then ye ’ll can tell her that I recommended it ; that ’ll set her to the laughing ; and I wouldnae wonder but what that was the next best .
#Text=But see to the pair of them !
#Text=If I didnae feel just sure of the lassie , and that she was awful pleased and chief with Alan , I would think there was some kind of hocus-pocus about you . ”
#Text=“ And is she so pleased with ye , then , Alan ? ” I asked .
#Text=“ She thinks a heap of me , ” says he .
#Text=“ And I ’m no like you :
#Text=I ’m one that can tell .
#Text=That she does — she thinks a heap of Alan .
#Text=And troth ! I ’m thinking a good deal of him mysel ; and with your permission , Shaws , I ’ll be getting a wee yont amang the bents , so that I can see what way James goes . ”
#Text=One after another went , till I was left alone beside the breakfast table ; James to Dunkirk , Alan dogging him , Catriona up the stairs to her own chamber .

#Text=I could very well understand how she should avoid to be alone with me ; yet was none the better pleased with it for that , and bent my mind to entrap her to an interview before the men returned .
#Text=Upon the whole , the best appeared to me to do like Alan .
#Text=If I was out of view among the sandhills , the fine morning would decoy her forth ; and once I had her in the open , I could please myself .
